thread.title: What You Need To Know About PMQs
thread.title_full: What You Need To Know About PMQs

author: news.sky
title: What You Need To Know About PMQs
text:
Prime Minister's Questions was dominated by tax credits and the Labour U-turn on backing George Osborne's plans to reduce the deficit. :: So was it any good? 
So we are in series one, episode two of Prime Minister's Questions starring David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn.
Mr Corbyn continued where he left off after episode one by asking readers' questions - which appeared to be a bit of a winning formula back in the session before Parliament broke for the party conferences.
Mr Cameron still appears less comfortable with the "new politics" than the Punch and Judy politics he's used to - no punch, not blows landed - and it's certainly taken some of the heat out of exchanges.
Play video "Labour Wants More Borrowing Forever" Video: Labour Wants More Borrowing Forever As Sky News editor at large Adam Boulton observed: "PMQs turning into PM's Surgery. Reasonably questions, reasonably answered. Won't damage either JC or DC. JC does not rise to bait."
:: What was the main theme? 
The economy - and welfare.
Mr Corbyn was straight out of the box with a question from single mother Kelly, who will lose tax credits when the cuts hit in April. Kelly's question was: how much will I lose in tax credits?
Mr Cameron replied with this stock answer on this subject: people will be £20 a week better off because of the new National Living Wage.
Mr Corbyn: Kelly will lose £1,800 a year from April.
He said he had 2,000 questions about tax credits from the public.
Mr Cameron hit back with jibes about the Labour U-turn on the fiscal charter. ( On Tuesday, the shadow chancellor moved from backing George Osborne's plan to run a budget surplus by 2019/2020 to not backing it . Has subsequently confessed to "confusing Labour MPs").
The Prime Minister aimed some five jibes at Mr Corbyn on the same subject, saying that Labour policy now appeared to be about "borrowing forever".
Mr Corbyn did not bite. However, he didn't answer the question either.
:: Best zingers? 
Nothing amazing but...
Mr Corbyn asked a question from Matthew, who cannot get on the housing ladder despite earning a reasonable wage. There was laughter from the Government benches.
Mr Corbyn said: "This might be funny to some people but it's not funny for Matthew."
And then there was Mr Cameron's response to SNP MP Angus Robertson question over whether the Government had learnt from the mistakes of Afghanistan, Iraq and Libya.
Mr Cameron said he could not remember a question with so many mistakes in it.
:: Funny bits? 
When Mr Corbyn accused Mr Cameron of not answering questions, there was plenty of noise in the chamber. Mr Corbyn was asked to calm down and was accused of chuntering by Speaker John Bercow.
The response: "I'm totally calm and have no intention chuntering."
:: Anything else we should know? 
That Call Me Dave biography made a reappearance when the Prime Minister was asked when he knew that Lord Ashcroft was a non dom. 
It's a question he has refused to answer before and refused to answer properly again.
He did tell MPs he had got a free copy of the book.
And as an aside, apparently Mr Corbyn's spokesman, Kevin Slocombe, was stopped from entering the chamber because he wasn't wearing a tie.
He hastily borrowed one.
